It was great meeting the team, thank you for all of your hard work to protect the Ipswich River. Count me as a partner.
The group also focuses on reducing the impact of climate change. The river experienced two severe droughts and then major flooding in the last few years.
Tomorrow the group and my friend @SenBruceTarr are holding a community meeting to try to build consensus around ways to protect the river. I’ll be following it closely.

For a small a mount of money, we can connect communities that receive water from other sources to each other, and potentially reduce costs if you factor in all the costs that go into getting clean water to families across our region.
The team at @ipswich_river is fighting to protect the river. They have a 2-part strategy.

The first is reducing use. About 20 percent of the water taken from the river leaks out of the old pipes that carry it to your faucet—some of the pipes are so old they’re made of wood. And about half of the water taken from the river goes to watering lawns.
The second strategy is helping communities find alternative supplies—expect more from me on that front in the next few months.
The river supplies 5 million people from Wilmington to Lynn with water, and that’s part of the problem. Because many communities draw from the river in the summer, it is drying up.
Today I met with the team at @ipswich_river, the protectors of the Ipswich River, one of the 10 most endangered rivers in the United States. https://t.co/3qkopI790h

So long as the filibuster remains in place, efforts to reform our gun laws, strengthen voting rights and address climate change will be held hostage by this undemocratic rule of Senate procedure. Give Americans the legislative voice they deserve. Abolish the filibuster.

Throughout history, the filibuster was used to block landmark civil rights legislation, uphold segregation and deny protections for African Americans. It’s a relic of Jim Crow that has no place in our lawmaking process today.

Republicans will say that the filibuster was created intentionally to make the Senate more bipartisan. But, that’s simply not true. Not only does the Constitution make no mention of this procedural wall, but it assumes that legislative decisions would be made by *majority* vote.

The filibuster allows lawmakers elected by a minority of voters to exercise veto power over any and all laws-even on issues that the majority of the American people support. For instance, while nearly 70% of Americans support gun reform, we still may never see reform of any kind.
To protect Americans from gun violence, we need to fundamentally change how the government works: We need to abolish the filibuster. Let me tell you why.  🧵
@POTUS Congress needs to get this done. Let's go.
